blocks.name: avril1
blocks.content: Poisson d'Avril's Theorem. This theorem is noted for its _Selbstdokumentieren_ property, which means, literally, "self-documenting" and recalls the principle of _quidquid german dictum sit, altum viditur_, often used in set theory. Starting with the seemingly simple yet profound fact that any object ` x ` equals itself (proved by Tarski in 1965; see Lemma 6 of [Tarski] p. 68), we demonstrate that the power set of the real numbers, as a relation on the value of the imaginary unit, does not conjoin with an empty relation on the product of the additive and multiplicative identity elements, leading to this startling conclusion that has left even seasoned professional mathematicians scratching their heads. (Contributed by Prof. Loof Lirpa, 1-Apr-2005.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.) _A reply to skeptics can be found at ~ mmnotes.txt , under the 1-Apr-2006 entry_.
blocks.origin:
thm avril1(class c0, class c1) {
  |- wn(wa(wbr(c0, cpw(cr), cfv(ci, nat1)), wbr(c1, emptycls, co(nat0, cmul, nat1))))
} = {
  mpbir(wn(wa(wbr(c0, cpw(cr), cfv(ci, nat1)), wbr(c1, emptycls, co(nat0, cmul, nat1)))), wn(wa(wbr(c0, cpw(cxp(cnr, csn(c0r))), cio(hs0, wbr(nat1, cop(c0r, c1r), cv(hs0)))), wbr(c1, emptycls, co(nat0, cmul, nat1)))))
  intnan(wbr(c0, cpw(cxp(cnr, csn(c0r))), cio(hs0, wbr(nat1, cop(c0r, c1r), cv(hs0)))), wbr(c1, emptycls, co(nat0, cmul, nat1)))
  mtbir(wbr(c1, emptycls, co(nat0, cmul, nat1)), wcel(cop(c1, nat0), emptycls))
  pm2.61i(wn(wcel(cop(c1, nat0), emptycls)), wcel(cop(c1, nat0), universe))
  vtocleg(hs1, cop(c1, nat0), universe, wn(wcel(cop(c1, nat0), emptycls)))
  mtbii(wceq(cv(hs1), cop(c1, nat0)), wcel(cop(c1, nat0), emptycls), wcel(cv(hs1), emptycls))
  mpbi(wn(wcel(cv(hs1), emptycls)), wceq(cv(hs1), cv(hs1)))
  equid(hs1)
  con2bii(wceq(cv(hs1), cv(hs1)), wcel(cv(hs1), emptycls))
  abeq2i(hs1, emptycls, wn(wceq(cv(hs1), cv(hs1))))
  dfnul2(hs1)
  eleq1(cv(hs1), cop(c1, nat0), emptycls)
  con3i(wcel(cop(c1, nat0), universe), wcel(cop(c1, nat0), emptycls))
  elex(cop(c1, nat0), emptycls)
  bitri(wbr(c1, emptycls, co(nat0, cmul, nat1)), wcel(cop(c1, nat0), emptycls), wcel(cop(c1, co(nat0, cmul, nat1)), emptycls))
  df-br(c1, emptycls, co(nat0, cmul, nat1))
  eleq1i(cop(c1, co(nat0, cmul, nat1)), emptycls, cop(c1, nat0))
  opeq2i(c1, co(nat0, cmul, nat1), nat0)
  mulid1i(nat0)
  0cn()
  notbii(wa(wbr(c0, cpw(cr), cfv(ci, nat1)), wbr(c1, emptycls, co(nat0, cmul, nat1))), wa(wbr(c0, cpw(cxp(cnr, csn(c0r))), cio(hs0, wbr(nat1, cop(c0r, c1r), cv(hs0)))), wbr(c1, emptycls, co(nat0, cmul, nat1))))
  anbi1i(wbr(c0, cpw(cr), cfv(ci, nat1)), wbr(c1, emptycls, co(nat0, cmul, nat1)), wbr(c0, cpw(cxp(cnr, csn(c0r))), cio(hs0, wbr(nat1, cop(c0r, c1r), cv(hs0)))))
  bitri(wbr(c0, cpw(cr), cfv(ci, nat1)), wbr(c0, cpw(cxp(cnr, csn(c0r))), cio(hs0, wbr(nat1, cop(c0r, c1r), cv(hs0)))), wbr(c0, cpw(cr), cio(hs0, wbr(nat1, cop(c0r, c1r), cv(hs0)))))
  breq2i(c0, cpw(cr), cfv(ci, nat1), cio(hs0, wbr(nat1, cop(c0r, c1r), cv(hs0))))
  eqtri(cfv(ci, nat1), cio(hs0, wbr(nat1, cop(c0r, c1r), cv(hs0))), cfv(cop(c0r, c1r), nat1))
  fveq1i(ci, nat1, cop(c0r, c1r))
  df-i()
  df-fv(hs0, cop(c0r, c1r), nat1)
  breqi(c0, cpw(cr), cio(hs0, wbr(nat1, cop(c0r, c1r), cv(hs0))), cpw(cxp(cnr, csn(c0r))))
  ax-mp(wceq(cpw(cr), cpw(cxp(cnr, csn(c0r)))), wceq(cr, cxp(cnr, csn(c0r))))
  df-r()
  3eqtr4g(cpw(cr), cpw(cxp(cnr, csn(c0r))), cab(hs2, wss(cv(hs2), cr)), cab(hs2, wss(cv(hs2), cxp(cnr, csn(c0r)))), wceq(cr, cxp(cnr, csn(c0r))))
  abbidv(hs2, wceq(cr, cxp(cnr, csn(c0r))), wss(cv(hs2), cr), wss(cv(hs2), cxp(cnr, csn(c0r))))
  sseq2(cr, cxp(cnr, csn(c0r)), cv(hs2))
  df-pw(hs2, cr)
  df-pw(hs2, cxp(cnr, csn(c0r)))
  diff.hs1.c(cop(c1, nat0))
  diff.hs1.w(wn(wcel(cop(c1, nat0), emptycls)))
  diff.hs0.c(nat1)
  diff.hs0.c(cop(c0r, c1r))
  diff.hs2.w(wceq(cr, cxp(cnr, csn(c0r))))
  diff.hs2.c(cr)
  diff.hs2.c(cxp(cnr, csn(c0r)))
}

thm avril1(class c0, class c1) {
  ‚ä¢ ¬¨(c0[P(‚Ñù)](i ` 1)‚àß c1[‚àÖ](0[√ó]1))
} = {
  mpbir(¬¨(c0[P(‚Ñù)](i ` 1)‚àß c1[‚àÖ](0[√ó]1)), ¬¨(c0[P((‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 }))]iota(hs0, 1[< 0, 1 >]hs0)‚àß c1[‚àÖ](0[√ó]1)))
  intnan(c0[P((‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 }))]iota(hs0, 1[< 0, 1 >]hs0), c1[‚àÖ](0[√ó]1))
  mtbir(c1[‚àÖ](0[√ó]1), < c1, 0 > ‚àà ‚àÖ)
  pm2.61i(¬¨ < c1, 0 > ‚àà ‚àÖ, < c1, 0 > ‚àà ùïå)
  vtocleg(hs1, < c1, 0 >, universe, ¬¨ < c1, 0 > ‚àà ‚àÖ)
  mtbii(hs1 = < c1, 0 >, < c1, 0 > ‚àà ‚àÖ, hs1 ‚àà ‚àÖ)
  mpbi(¬¨ hs1 ‚àà ‚àÖ, hs1 = hs1)
  equid(hs1)
  con2bii(hs1 = hs1, hs1 ‚àà ‚àÖ)
  abeq2i(hs1, emptycls, ¬¨ hs1 = hs1)
  dfnul2(hs1)
  eleq1(hs1, < c1, 0 >, emptycls)
  con3i(< c1, 0 > ‚àà ùïå, < c1, 0 > ‚àà ‚àÖ)
  elex(< c1, 0 >, emptycls)
  bitri(c1[‚àÖ](0[√ó]1), < c1, 0 > ‚àà ‚àÖ, < c1,(0[√ó]1)> ‚àà ‚àÖ)
  df-br(c1, emptycls, (0[√ó]1))
  eleq1i(< c1,(0[√ó]1)>, emptycls, < c1, 0 >)
  opeq2i(c1, (0[√ó]1), nat0)
  mulid1i(nat0)
  0cn()
  notbii((c0[P(‚Ñù)](i ` 1)‚àß c1[‚àÖ](0[√ó]1)), (c0[P((‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 }))]iota(hs0, 1[< 0, 1 >]hs0)‚àß c1[‚àÖ](0[√ó]1)))
  anbi1i(c0[P(‚Ñù)](i ` 1), c1[‚àÖ](0[√ó]1), c0[P((‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 }))]iota(hs0, 1[< 0, 1 >]hs0))
  bitri(c0[P(‚Ñù)](i ` 1), c0[P((‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 }))]iota(hs0, 1[< 0, 1 >]hs0), c0[P(‚Ñù)]iota(hs0, 1[< 0, 1 >]hs0))
  breq2i(c0, P(‚Ñù), (i ` 1), iota(hs0, 1[< 0, 1 >]hs0))
  eqtri((i ` 1), iota(hs0, 1[< 0, 1 >]hs0), (< 0, 1 > ` 1))
  fveq1i(ci, nat1, < 0, 1 >)
  df-i()
  df-fv(hs0, < 0, 1 >, nat1)
  breqi(c0, P(‚Ñù), iota(hs0, 1[< 0, 1 >]hs0), P((‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 })))
  ax-mp(P(‚Ñù)= P((‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 })), ‚Ñù =(‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 }))
  df-r()
  3eqtr4g(P(‚Ñù), P((‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 })), { hs2 | hs2 ‚äÜ ‚Ñù }, { hs2 | hs2 ‚äÜ(‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 })}, ‚Ñù =(‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 }))
  abbidv(hs2, ‚Ñù =(‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 }), hs2 ‚äÜ ‚Ñù, hs2 ‚äÜ(‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 }))
  sseq2(cr, (‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 }), hs2)
  df-pw(hs2, cr)
  df-pw(hs2, (‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 }))
  diff.hs1.c(< c1, 0 >)
  diff.hs1.w(¬¨ < c1, 0 > ‚àà ‚àÖ)
  diff.hs0.c(nat1)
  diff.hs0.c(< 0, 1 >)
  diff.hs2.w(‚Ñù =(‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 }))
  diff.hs2.c(cr)
  diff.hs2.c((‚Ñù¬± √ó { 0 }))
}

blocks.name: 2bornot2b
blocks.content: The law of excluded middle. Act III, Theorem 1 of Shakespeare, _Hamlet, Prince of Denmark_ (1602). Its author leaves its proof as an exercise for the reader - "To be, or not to be: that is the question" - starting a trend that has become standard in modern-day textbooks, serving to make the frustrated reader feel inferior, or in some cases to mask the fact that the author does not know its solution. (Contributed by Prof. Loof Lirpa, 1-Apr-2006.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: helloworld
blocks.content: The classic "Hello world" benchmark has been translated into 314 computer programming languages - see ~ http://www.roesler-ac.de/wolfram/hello.htm . However, for many years it eluded a proof that it is more than just a conjecture, even though a wily mathematician once claimed, "I have discovered a truly marvelous proof of this, which this margin is too narrow to contain." Using an IBM 709 mainframe, a team of mathematicians led by Prof. Loof Lirpa, at the New College of Tahiti, were finally able put it rest with a remarkably short proof only 4 lines long. (Contributed by Prof. Loof Lirpa, 1-Apr-2007.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: 1p1e2apr1
blocks.content: One plus one equals two. Using proof-shortening techniques pioneered by Mr. Mel L. O'Cat, along with the latest supercomputer technology, Prof. Loof Lirpa and colleagues were able to shorten Whitehead and Russell's 360-page proof that 1+1=2 in _Principia Mathematica_ to this remarkable proof only two steps long, thus establishing a new world's record for this famous theorem. (Contributed by Prof. Loof Lirpa, 1-Apr-2008.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: eqid1
blocks.content: Law of identity (reflexivity of class equality). Theorem 6.4 of [Quine] p. 41. This law is thought to have originated with Aristotle (_Metaphysics_, Book VII, Part 17). It is one of the three axioms of Ayn Rand's philosophy (_Atlas Shrugged_, Part Three, Chapter VII). While some have proposed extending Rand's axiomatization to include Compassion and Kindness, others fear that such an extension may flirt with logical inconsistency. (Contributed by Stefan Allan, 1-Apr-2009.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: 1div0apr
blocks.content: Division by zero is forbidden! If we try, we encounter the DO NOT ENTER sign, which in mathematics means it is foolhardy to venture any further, possibly putting the underlying fabric of reality at risk. Based on a dare by David A. Wheeler. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 1-Apr-2014.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
thm 1div0apr() {
  |- wceq(co(nat1, cdiv, nat0), emptycls)
} = {
  mp2an(wceq(co(nat1, cdiv, nat0), emptycls), wceq(cdm(cdiv), cxp(cc, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)))), wn(wa(wcel(nat1, cc), wcel(nat0, cdif(cc, csn(nat0))))))
  dmmpt2(hs0, hs1, cdiv, cc, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), crio(hs2, cc, wceq(co(cv(hs1), cmul, cv(hs2)), cv(hs0))))
  df-div(hs0, hs1, hs2)
  riotaex(hs2, cc, wceq(co(cv(hs1), cmul, cv(hs2)), cv(hs0)))
  ax-mp(wn(wa(wcel(nat1, cc), wcel(nat0, cdif(cc, csn(nat0))))), wceq(nat0, nat0))
  eqid(nat0)
  necon2bi(nat0, nat0, wa(wcel(nat1, cc), wcel(nat0, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)))))
  adantl(wcel(nat1, cc), wcel(nat0, cdif(cc, csn(nat0))), wne(nat0, nat0))
  eldifsni(nat0, cc, nat0)
  ndmovg(cdiv, cc, cdif(cc, csn(nat0)), nat1, nat0)
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.c(cc)
  diff.hs0.c(cdif(cc, csn(nat0)))
  diff.hs1.c(cc)
  diff.hs1.c(cdif(cc, csn(nat0)))
  diff.hs0.s(hs2)
  diff.hs1.s(hs2)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm 1div0apr() {
  ‚ä¢ (1[√∑]0)= ‚àÖ
} = {
  mp2an((1[√∑]0)= ‚àÖ, dom(√∑)=(‚ÑÇ √ó(‚ÑÇ \ { 0 })), ¬¨(1 ‚àà ‚ÑÇ ‚àß 0 ‚àà(‚ÑÇ \ { 0 })))
  dmmpt2(hs0, hs1, cdiv, cc, (‚ÑÇ \ { 0 }), iota(hs2 ‚àà ‚ÑÇ,(hs1[√ó]hs2)= hs0))
  df-div(hs0, hs1, hs2)
  riotaex(hs2, cc, (hs1[√ó]hs2)= hs0)
  ax-mp(¬¨(1 ‚àà ‚ÑÇ ‚àß 0 ‚àà(‚ÑÇ \ { 0 })), 0 = 0)
  eqid(nat0)
  necon2bi(nat0, nat0, (1 ‚àà ‚ÑÇ ‚àß 0 ‚àà(‚ÑÇ \ { 0 })))
  adantl(1 ‚àà ‚ÑÇ, 0 ‚àà(‚ÑÇ \ { 0 }), 0 ‚â† 0)
  eldifsni(nat0, cc, nat0)
  ndmovg(cdiv, cc, (‚ÑÇ \ { 0 }), nat1, nat0)
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.c(cc)
  diff.hs0.c((‚ÑÇ \ { 0 }))
  diff.hs1.c(cc)
  diff.hs1.c((‚ÑÇ \ { 0 }))
  diff.hs0.s(hs2)
  diff.hs1.s(hs2)
}

blocks.name: topnfbey
blocks.content: Nothing seems to be impossible to Prof. Lirpa. After years of intensive research, he managed to find a proof that when given a chance to reach infinity, one could indeed go beyond, thus giving formal soundness to Buzz Lightyear's motto "To infinity... and beyond!" (Contributed by Prof. Loof Lirpa, 1-Apr-2020.) (Revised by Thierry Arnoux, 2-Aug-2020.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
thm topnfbey(class c0) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, co(nat0, cfz, cpnf)), wbr(cpnf, clt, c0))
} = {
  pm2.21i(wcel(c0, co(nat0, cfz, cpnf)), wbr(cpnf, clt, c0))
  mtbir(wcel(c0, co(nat0, cfz, cpnf)), wcel(c0, emptycls))
  noel(c0)
  eleq2i(c0, co(nat0, cfz, cpnf), emptycls)
  ax-mp(wceq(co(nat0, cfz, cpnf), emptycls), wn(wa(wcel(nat0, cz), wcel(cpnf, cz))))
  intnan(wcel(nat0, cz), wcel(cpnf, cz))
  mto(wcel(cpnf, cz), wbr(cpnf, clt, cpnf))
  ax-mp(wn(wbr(cpnf, clt, cpnf)), wcel(cpnf, cxr))
  pnfxr()
  xrltnr(cpnf)
  syl(wcel(cpnf, cz), wbr(cpnf, clt, cpnf), wcel(cpnf, cr))
  zre(cpnf)
  ltpnf(cpnf)
  ndmov(nat0, cz, cpnf, cfz)
  fdmi(cfz, cxp(cz, cz), cpw(cz))
  fzf()
}
blocks.pretty:
thm topnfbey(class c0) {
  ‚ä¢ (c0 ‚àà(0[...]+‚àû)‚Üí +‚àû[<]c0)
} = {
  pm2.21i(c0 ‚àà(0[...]+‚àû), +‚àû[<]c0)
  mtbir(c0 ‚àà(0[...]+‚àû), c0 ‚àà ‚àÖ)
  noel(c0)
  eleq2i(c0, (0[...]+‚àû), emptycls)
  ax-mp((0[...]+‚àû)= ‚àÖ, ¬¨(0 ‚àà ‚Ñ§ ‚àß +‚àû ‚àà ‚Ñ§))
  intnan(0 ‚àà ‚Ñ§, +‚àû ‚àà ‚Ñ§)
  mto(+‚àû ‚àà ‚Ñ§, +‚àû[<]+‚àû)
  ax-mp(¬¨ +‚àû[<]+‚àû, +‚àû ‚àà ‚Ñù*)
  pnfxr()
  xrltnr(cpnf)
  syl(+‚àû ‚àà ‚Ñ§, +‚àû[<]+‚àû, +‚àû ‚àà ‚Ñù)
  zre(cpnf)
  ltpnf(cpnf)
  ndmov(nat0, cz, cpnf, cfz)
  fdmi(cfz, (‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§), P(‚Ñ§))
  fzf()
}
